explanation:
The correct calculation rounds 8.3 to 8 (since 0.3 < 0.5) and 12.9 to 13 (since 0.9 ≥ 0.5), yielding \(8 \times 13\).  
The student incorrectly calculated \(9 \times 12\), rounding 8.3 up to 9 and 12.9 down to 12.  

The flaw lies in reversing the rounding direction for both values:  
- 8.3 was rounded up despite being closer to 8, violating the "round down if decimal < 0.5" rule.  
- 12.9 was rounded down despite being closer to 13, ignoring the "round up if decimal ≥ 0.5" rule.  

This error stems from misapplying the rounding threshold (0.5) for both numbers. The student treated 8.3 as requiring an upward change and 12.9 as requiring a downward change, directly conflicting with standard rounding conventions.  

This explanation aligns with the misconceptions "Rounds up instead of down" (for 8.3) and "Rounds down instead of up" (for 12.9). It is distinct from "rounding must change the number," as the correct answer also changes 12.9 to 13, demonstrating the error is about direction, not the act of changing itself.
